body:
I got this working as well.

Most of our queries were being successfully executed by superset, but all the queries with `CASE` statement were being thought as a "threat" by our firewall. After making the necessary changes in our firewall, those queries also started working fine.
What was the motivation behind this feature?
@vylc can comment more on the motivation, IIRC other tools similar to SQL Lab have this functionality and users requested it.

I think datasources currently have a unique constraint on "database + schema + table_name", which prevents people from creating many diverging datasources that point to the same physical table.

For reasons mentioned here and other concerns around diverging needs from different owners around the same datasource, I think we should remove that constraint.
Here it is with padding-bottom: 4px;
LGTM

Merged the related PR. Outstanding items:
* Removing the round "+" button on list view: decided to leave that open for discussion. Currently the template is shared by all entities in Flask App Builder. I could change it to make it such that some models would use an alternate template without the "+" button but it would make the view inconsistent across entities. Also some users might be used in using the button and look for it. Open for discussion/change, but left it out for now.
* Didn't change the color on "Filter List" to our brand-primary, just because it was a bit tricky to do that. It currently uses a borderless button because it's a dropdown button (menu expands as you click it, and it's a bootstrap thing. When removing the hack showing the border, it overflowed and I was not in the mood for css tweaking today :) I agree that this is confusing though. The "Filter List" and plus sign don't seem like 2 different actions...
@graceguo-supercat no problem,  I would have done, today.

@kristw echoing @betodealmeida 's comment above. Mostly a time saver for when user chooses an autocomplete selection from standard SQL predicates like SELECT, WHERE, etc. The AC action is via Enter or tab, and the next keystroke is space, which disrupts flow of typing.
Very particular, but something some users are used to. I've seen this implemented as an editor setting as well.

I think you're just missing the database dependency for MySQL. Try the following:

```
$ pip install mysqlclient
```

[reference](https://superset.incubator.apache.org/installation.html#database-dependencies)

This is an important bugfix when you want to add the same table via multiple schemas in vertica or when you have a presto table replicated across multiple different databases. Logically speaking a table is only unique within the <database, schema>.
Addressed comments.
Ping @mistercrunch @john-bodley any chance of getting additional comments or merging this?

@cychiang so what is the default username and password for superset webui when installed with this script.

Hi @charles-zhan, I assume you deploy the superset in Kubernetes cluster and want to know the username and password when open the web UI.

According to the document [here](https://superset.incubator.apache.org/installation.html#getting-started) you need to create username and password by your own. 
Here is the step to create the username and password.
1. Invoke `superset-init` to create an admin account by `kubectl exec -ti ${your_pods_name} -- superset-init`
2. You will enter the interactive mode, and it will request you enter information to create the credential.

3. After you complete all steps, you should be able to login with username and password you provided on the previous stage.
